dt: {bc}partly or totally {d_link|unlike|unlike:1} in nature, form, or quality {bc}{sx|dissimilar||}
often followed by {it}from, than{/it}, or chiefly British {it}to{/it}

dt.t: small, neat hand, very {wi}different{/wi} from the captain's tottery characters
vastly {wi}different{/wi} in size than it was twenty-five years ago
a very {wi}different{/wi} situation to the … one under which we live

usages.pl: Is it {parahw}different{/parahw} than or different from?
pt: Numerous commentators have condemned {it}different than{/it} in spite of its use since the 17th century by many of the best-known names in English literature. It is nevertheless standard and is even recommended in many handbooks when followed by a clause, because insisting on {it}from{/it} in such instances often produces clumsy or wordy formulations. {it}Different from{/it}, the generally safe choice, is more common especially when it is followed by a noun or pronoun.

{sc}different{/sc} {sc}diverse{/sc} {sc}divergent{/sc} {sc}disparate{/sc} {sc}various{/sc} mean unlike in kind or character. {sc}different{/sc} may imply little more than separateness but it may also imply contrast or contrariness.
{sc}diverse{/sc} implies both distinctness and marked contrast.

pt.t: such {it}diverse{/it} interests as dancing and football

pt: {sc}divergent{/sc} implies movement away from each other and unlikelihood of ultimate meeting or reconciliation.
{sc}various{/sc} stresses the number of sorts or kinds.

et: Middle English, borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin {it}different-, differens,{/it} present participle of {it}differre{/it} "to carry in varying directions, delay, {et_link|differ|differ}"
shortdef: partly or totally unlike in nature, form, or quality : dissimilar —often followed by from, than, or chiefly British to

dt.t: The sport has changed. It's a very/completely {it}different animal{/it} today.
Reading modern English is one thing, but understanding Shakespeare is an entirely {it}different beast{/it}.

stems: march to the beat of a different drummer

dt: used in phrases such as {phrase}march to the beat of a different drummer{/phrase} to describe a person who thinks, lives, or behaves in an unusual way

dt.t: His strange behavior was no surprise—he had always {it}marched to (the beat of) a different drummer{/it}.
Her friends went to college, but she {phrase}heard a different drummer{/phrase} and moved to the city to be an actor.

shortdef: —used in phrases such as march to the beat of a different drummer to describe a person who thinks, lives, or behaves in an unusual way

meta.id: a horse of a different color
stems: a horse of a different color

hwi.hw: a horse of a different color

dt.t: That's what we'll do when he gets here. But if he doesn't show up … well, that's {it}a horse of a different color{/it}.

shortdef: a very different thing or issue

dt.t: He's a pretty good writer, but she's {it}in a different league{/it} altogether.
I see things {it}in a different light{/it} now.

dt: {bc}to change the way one talks about something {bc}to have a different opinion about something

dt.t: They say they're not worried about money, but once they see how much the new equipment will cost, they'll be {it}singing a different tune{/it}.

shortdef: to change the way one talks about something : to have a different opinion about something

dt: {bc}to show that something different is true from what someone says is true

dt.t: He said he wasn't at the scene of the crime, but the fingerprints {it}tell a different story{/it}.

shortdef: to show that something different is true from what someone says is true
